Recognising rights of senior citizens
item.description: With the number of people in their old age (65 years and above) remaining at around 12 million in 2025, representing 7.0 per cent of the total population, Bangladesh is going through a fast demographic transition. Since people need different types of support and care in old age, their families, the

item.title: Private sector credit slump rings alarm bells
Forbidden Jokes
item.description: Last month, ABC suspended late-night talk show host Jimmy Kimmel – a frequent critic of US President Donald Trump – after pressure from the government. While Kimmel was reinstated, Trump will likely continue to threaten comedians, because nothing is more damaging to a demagogue than being laughed at.

item.title: Putin’s Polycrisis
item.description: Despite mounting economic and demographic pressures, Russian President Vladimir Putin will continue to feed the war machine so long as he gains ground in Ukraine. To change his calculus, Western leaders must strengthen sanctions against the Kremlin, provide advanced weapons to Ukraine, and incentivize Russian brain drain.

item.title: How law denies children of child marriage essential services

item.title: Blaming Russia Won’t Stop the Populist Right
item.description: Russian meddling and disinformation have been an important subtext of recent European elections in Moldova and the Czech Republic, as well as in earlier elections where right-wing populists have done well. But fixation on the Kremlin obscures a deeper, more troubling reality: the genuine popular appeal of right-wing ideology.

item.title: When excellence becomes invisible: The thin line between ‘Business As Usual’ and outstanding performance
Total Victory in Gaza Is a Delusion
item.description: Even if Hamas is ultimately “defeated" in Gaza, the blow it has dealt to Israel amounts to a psychological victory that will remain etched in the collective memory of the Palestinian people. Conversely, an Israeli military “victory” would imply a staggering moral and strategic defeat.

item.title: Execution of Blue Network Programme

All water channels such as rivers,

item.title: Bangladesh's animation dream: From margins to mainstream
item.description: Bangladesh's animators have been busy. For more than a decade they have produced sleek, colourful sequences for global entertainment giants -- from television commercials to mobile games -- often without anyone knowing the work was done in Dhaka rather than Delhi or Manila. The talent is there; the

item.title: Curbing anthrax outbreak
item.description: Anthrax has been in the news in Bangladesh for nearly a month. There are reports of anthrax infection in Pirgachha upazila of the northern district of Rangpur. Though ruminating, hooved and grazing animals like cow, goat, lamb, etc., are usually infected by anthrax, humans can also contract the dis

item.title: How the Democrats Can “Win” the US Government Shutdown
item.description: To prevail against a would-be autocrat, US Democrats should make an argument about democracy. Not only has a Republican-controlled government closed, but the Republican-controlled Congress is simply handing power to an executive who has signaled clearly his intention to act illegally and unconstitutionally.

item.title: What Mayors Need to Lead
item.description: As power in the United Kingdom continues to shift from London to the rest of the country, and as the European Union looks to city governments to drive an economic recovery and more, people across the continent will increasingly be counting on local leaders. The task now is to make sure those leaders are equipped for the task.

item.title: Why no urgency to contain dengue?
item.description: Frequent spells of rainfall over the last couple of months have created ideal breeding conditions for mosquitoes. While all three genera of mosquitoes---aedes, anopheles and culex---have proliferated due to the favourable conditions, the most dreaded one is aedes that causes dengue and chikungunya.

item.title: Fishing bans fail to arrest decline in hilsha population
item.description: The breeding season ban of 22 days on catching of hilsha has become effective from October 4 last. This yearly legal restriction was introduced in 2008 for 11 days covering a pre- and post-full-moon period. But a study found that hilsha is used to spawning during the new moon or dark moon too. item.title: Rebuilding trust in credit ratings

Effective CSR is embedded in the business, not siloed in a foundation
India’s Strategic Balancing Act
item.description: Strategic autonomy is not about oscillating between poles, but about preventing one's own agenda from being subsumed by that of another power. For India today, this means preventing escalation with China without succumbing to the illusion of partnership, and negotiating firmly with the US without disrupting constructive engagement.

item.title: Africa’s Rare-Earth Opportunity
item.description: As global demand for critical minerals surges, Africa has a once-in-a-century opportunity to break the “resource curse” and convert its vast natural wealth into economic and social transformation. But, to seize it, the continent’s leaders must avoid falling into old traps.

item.title: The UN Without America
item.description: Though multilateralism remains as important as ever to defend human rights, support peace and security, and deliver cooperative solutions to shared problems, the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly painted a bleak picture of the institution’s prospects. To avoid fading into irrelevance, the UN must transform itself – including by radically reducing its dependence on the United States.

item.title: Record October rainfall and its implications
